medium_description_en: Calculates biologically effective dose (BED) and equivalent dose (EQD2) for cancer radiotherapy.

seo.meta_description_en: The Radiation Biologically Effective Dose (BED) Calculator calculates BED and equivalent dose (EQD2) for cancer radiotherapy.
seo.keywords_en: Gy fractions, biologically effective dose, tumor, 2 Gy, 2Gy, dose fractionation, fractionation, radiation fractionation

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients undergoing radiation (to compare different fractionation regimens).
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Note that BED is the biologically effective dose, not biologically equivalent dose.

  • EQD2 is the equivalent dose in 2-Gy fractions.

  • An α/β ratio of 10 is typically used for early-responding tissues and tumors.

  • An α/β ratio of 3 is typically used for late-responding tissues, such as normal tissue.

  • Prostate cancer has a low α/β ratio of ~1.5.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Compares different fractionation regimens with hypofractionation or stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) using a common numerical score.

next_steps.advice_en: Can also be used to determine total dose received over multiple radiation courses.

about.formula_en:
BED = D x (1 + [d / (α/β)])

EQD2 = D x ([d + (α/β)] / [2 Gy + (α/β)])  

 

Where variables are as follows:

Variable

Description

BED

Biologically effective dose, in Gy

EQD2

Equivalent dose in 2-Gy fractions, in Gy

d

Dose per fraction, in Gy

D

Total dose (number of fractions x dose per fraction), in Gy

α/β ratio

Property of irradiated tissue

Original/Primary Reference.text: Fowler JF. The linear-quadratic formula and progress in fractionated radiotherapy. Br J Radiol. 1989;62(740):679-94.

Other References.text: Fowler JF. 21 years of biologically effective dose. Br J Radiol. 2010;83(991):554-68.

creator_info.about_en: John F. Fowler, DSc, PhD, FInsTP, (d. 2016) was the director of the Gray Laboratory at Mount Vernon Hospital in England, UK. He also served as president of the Hospital Physicists Association, European Society of Radiation Biology, and the British Institute of Radiology. Dr. Fowler’s primary research was focused on dose fractionation and tumor control.
